  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
Some extraordinary events came out of the G-8 Summit
  today. Russian President Vladimir Putin proposed a radical alternative to
  President Bush’s plan to install new missile systems in Europe. The missiles are a sore point for the Russians,
  but surprisingly, President Bush called the idea "interesting."
  Also, German chancellor Angela Merkel hailed a global warming plan she and
  the other leaders agreed upon as a "huge success." The goal is to
  cut greenhouse gases in half by 2050. But will the plan actually hold
  countries accountable? Jim Axelrod will have the story. 
 
Meanwhile, our chief foreign correspondent Lara
  Logan is in Baghdad.
  She'll have a look at U.S.
  efforts to suppress violence in the Shiite stronghold of Sadr City.
  This comes as its influential leader Muqtada al Sadr spoke to an Iraqi state
  television station just two weeks after he showed up in public to condemn the
  U.S.
  presence.
 
Also, David Martin will tell us about the
  discouraging new progress report on Iraq that emerged during
  confirmation hearings for President Bush’s pick for war czar. 
 
In health news, new stem-cell research is making
  waves. Could the discovery that scientists reported this week be enough to
  break the political logjam over the issue? Dr. Jon LaPook will take a look.
 
Finally, our Richard Schlesinger met some old
  friends down in Kentucky.
  Two of them are named Sunshine Forever and Swan's Way and they're unlike any
  other retirees you've ever met.
 
I hope you'll join us.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
